I love snacking on fresh fruit like mango or papaya, especially if I'm in a place like Colombia or Ecuador where the fruits are super fresh and flavorful. It’s light, vegan, and gives me a quick energy boost.
Roasted chickpeas with a bit of chili powder make a great crunchy snack. It’s tasty, packed with protein, and feels like a little nod to Latin flavors without being heavy.

Plantain chips are another favorite—crispy, slightly sweet, and perfect for munching on while listening to some salsa or reggaeton. You can find them almost anywhere in South America, and they’re naturally vegan.
A classic choice for me is a slice of pizza from a local joint—easy to grab, filling, and hits the spot between meals.
I love grabbing some nachos loaded with cheese and jalapeños, especially from a fast food place with good Rock music vibes playing.
When I want something lighter but still tasty, I go for a small pasta salad or garlic knots—perfect for that quick energy boost.
A good snack between meals could be some thinly sliced prosciutto with a few olives—it's flavorful, protein-rich, and reminds me of the delicious cured meats I enjoyed while traveling in Italy.
I like having beef jerky or biltong as a snack; it's easy to carry around and gives me a satisfying meat fix without feeling heavy before my next meal.
When I want something quick but classy, I go for a small cheese and charcuterie plate, maybe with some nuts and dried fruits, while listening to a Mozart piano concerto to keep the vibe elegant.

If you want something spicy and vegan, try a Chilean pebre with a side of spicy quinoa salad. Pebre is a flavorful condiment made with cilantro, chili peppers, garlic, and onions that really packs a punch.

When I’m in Peru, I love ordering ají de quinua. It’s like a spicy quinoa stew made with ají amarillo, a Peruvian yellow chili pepper that’s both vibrant and hot, plus veggies and plant-based protein.

In Colombia, a great spicy vegan option is patacones with hogao sauce that’s been kicked up with extra chili peppers. The fried plantains are a perfect base for that tangy, spicy tomato and onion salsa.

If you're craving something spicy, I'd go for a spicy buffalo chicken sandwich from a good American fast-food joint. It’s got that kick and pairs perfectly with some fries—ideal for satisfying that heat craving while keeping it casual.

For a pasta twist, try spicy arrabbiata. It’s a classic Italian dish with a fiery tomato sauce loaded with chili peppers. It’s comforting but with a nice punch, perfect for someone who loves pasta but wants it with some spice.

If you’re in the mood for something different but still spicy, check out a Cajun-style blackened chicken burger. It’s packed with bold spices, and the southern US vibe adds a great rock ‘n’ roll kind of flavor to your meal!

If you’re in Spain and want something spicy, try the spicy chorizo dish, like chorizo al vino. It’s packed with flavor and has that nice kick from the paprika. Perfect when paired with a glass of Rioja and some classical guitar music in the background.

When in Italy, go for a spicy nduja spread or dish featuring nduja sausage from Calabria. It’s a spicy, spreadable pork sausage that adds heat without overwhelming the rich, meaty flavor—perfect for a more intense taste while enjoying some Vivaldi.

For a meat-based spicy dish in France, order the Toulouse sausage with a bit of a spicy mustard or pepper sauce. It’s hearty and a bit fiery, aligning well with the ambiance of a quaint bistro while listening to some Debussy.

You should visit Cusco, Peru. It’s rich in indigenous culture and history, with incredible Incan ruins like Machu Picchu nearby. Plus, you can explore local markets with fresh vegan options like quinoa and potatoes, while enjoying traditional Andean music.

Head to Buenos Aires, Argentina. The city’s vibrant tango scene offers deep cultural immersion, and there’s a growing number of vegan restaurants serving delicious plant-based takes on Argentine cuisine. Don’t miss live Latin jazz and salsa clubs for an authentic music experience.

Explore Cartagena, Colombia. It’s a colorful city with Afro-Caribbean influences, colonial architecture, and lively street festivals. You can find plenty of tropical fruits and vegan-friendly dishes, and enjoy reggae en Español and cumbia performances in local venues.
Check out New Orleans – the city’s got amazing cultural vibes, great jazz and rock scenes, plus tasty food like po’boys and jambalaya to enjoy between the music and museums.
Head to Los Angeles for a mix of stuff – you get iconic rock venues, tons of museums for cultural experiences, and loads of great fast food and pasta spots to keep you fueled while exploring.
Visit Austin, Texas – it’s known for live music festivals with a strong rock presence, rich local culture, and food trucks serving everything from Tex-Mex to creative pasta dishes.

Vienna is perfect for immersing yourself in culture. You can enjoy world-class classical concerts, explore grand palaces like Schönbrunn, and savor traditional Austrian dishes like Wiener Schnitzel and Tafelspitz.

Rome offers a rich cultural experience with its ancient history, stunning architecture, and vibrant art scene. Don’t miss tasting authentic Italian meat dishes such as Bistecca alla Fiorentina, and maybe catch an opera at Teatro dell'Opera di Roma.

Munich combines cultural heritage with excellent cuisine. Visit the museums, attend a classical concert at the Munich Residenz, and indulge in hearty Bavarian specialties like Schweinshaxe (pork knuckle) paired with local beer.

You should visit Mexico City! It’s packed with history, from the ancient Aztec ruins of Templo Mayor to the incredible National Museum of Anthropology. Plus, there are tons of vegan-friendly restaurants serving delicious traditional dishes like plant-based tacos and tamales. The city’s vibrant Latin music scene is a bonus—don’t miss catching live salsa or mariachi performances.

Buenos Aires is perfect for exploring rich history and museums. The Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes and the MALBA have impressive collections. You can also wander through historic neighborhoods like San Telmo with its colonial architecture. The city’s vegan options have grown a lot, with many cozy cafés offering empanadas, and you can immerse yourself in tango music and dance.

Quito in Ecuador offers a fantastic blend of colonial history and museums, like the Museo de la Ciudad and Casa del Alabado, showcasing pre-Columbian art. The Old Town is a UNESCO site with beautiful plazas and churches. You’ll find many vegan markets and eateries featuring fresh fruit juices and local plant-based dishes. Plus, the city often hosts lively Latin jazz and folk music events.

If you're into history and museums, Washington D.C. is a must-visit. You can check out the Smithsonian museums, like the National Museum of American History, and still grab some awesome burgers nearby. Plus, the city has some cool rock venues if you want to catch a live show.

New York City is packed with history and world-class museums like the Met and the Museum of Natural History. After exploring, you can indulge in some classic NYC pizza or pasta. Plus, the rock scene here is legendary, so you might catch a concert or hit up iconic music spots.

Chicago has a rich history and fantastic museums such as the Art Institute and the Field Museum. The deep-dish pizza is great for a fast food fix, and the city has a strong rock and blues heritage, with tons of live music venues to explore after your museum visits.

You should definitely visit Rome. The city is packed with ancient history, like the Colosseum and Roman Forum, plus world-class museums such as the Vatican Museums. After a day of exploring, you can enjoy traditional Italian meat dishes like osso buco or a hearty bistecca alla fiorentina. Classical music performances are common too, especially in historic venues.

Paris is another fantastic option. The Louvre is unparalleled for art and history enthusiasts, and the Musée d'Orsay offers incredible exhibits from the 19th century. For dinner, try classic French meat dishes like coq au vin or steak frites. You might even catch a classical concert at one of the city’s beautiful concert halls like the Philharmonie de Paris.

Vienna is perfect if you want a mix of museums and rich history, plus a strong classical music scene. You can visit the Kunsthistorisches Museum and explore the imperial palaces. The city is famous for its Wiener Schnitzel and other meat-centric dishes. Also, attending a performance by the Vienna Philharmonic or at the State Opera House would be a memorable cultural highlight.

For a long road trip through South America, I love a playlist that features a mix of classic and contemporary Latin music. Think artists like Celia Cruz, Juanes, and Natalia Lafourcade, with some upbeat salsa, cumbia, and reggaeton to keep the energy up. It’s great for singing along and really getting into the vibe of the region.

I usually create a road trip playlist filled with some iconic Latin indie and alternative artists like Mon Laferte, Bomba Estéreo, and Café Tacvba. Their sounds blend traditional Latin rhythms with modern beats, which makes for a cool and relaxed soundtrack while driving through beautiful landscapes.

My go-to playlist for a South American road trip includes a lot of upbeat tropical and Afro-Latin genres—think bachata from Romeo Santos, samba from Gilberto Gil, and some bossa nova classics like João Gilberto. It’s perfect for keeping the mood light and happy, especially when stopping at vegan-friendly roadside cafes along the way.

For a long road trip, I’d go with a classic rock playlist—think Led Zeppelin, The Rolling Stones, and AC/DC. It keeps the energy up, and their epic guitar riffs make the miles fly by. Plus, it pairs perfectly with some fast food stops like In-N-Out or Five Guys along the way.

I like mixing it up with some modern rock and fast-paced tracks for a long drive. Bands like The Killers, Foo Fighters, and Arctic Monkeys keep the vibe fresh. Of course, I’d plan stops in some iconic USA spots, grabbing pizza or loaded fries to refuel.

If I’m hitting the road, I load a playlist with road trip anthems—Tom Petty, Bruce Springsteen, and Guns N’ Roses are must-haves. Their music just feels made for the open highway. I’d pack plenty of pasta in a travel cooler, but also look out for local burger joints in small towns for a classic American experience.

A great playlist for a long road trip would be a mix of classical music from European composers like Beethoven, Chopin, and Tchaikovsky. Their symphonies and piano concertos keep the mood epic and engaging, especially when driving through scenic landscapes.

For something more upbeat but still classical, try a playlist featuring operatic arias and orchestral pieces from composers like Verdi, Mozart, and Wagner. It feels like a grand European tour, which pairs well with stops at traditional steak houses or local meat specialties along the way.

If you want to combine travel vibes with your love for meat-based meals, create a playlist inspired by European culinary regions—French chansons, Italian mandolins, and German folk tunes—interspersed with classical compositions. You can imagine savoring dishes like Bavarian sausages, Italian prosciutto, or French beef bourguignon as you drive.

When I travel, especially through South America, I love listening to traditional Latin music like salsa and cumbia. Artists like Celia Cruz and Carlos Vives always get me in the right mood and really connect me to the places I’m visiting.

For long flights or bus rides, I prefer upbeat Latin pop or reggaeton to keep my energy up. Bad Bunny and J Balvin have great tracks that make the journey fun and lively without losing that Latin vibe.

I also enjoy indie Latin American artists who blend traditional sounds with modern styles, like Natalia Lafourcade or Monsieur Periné. Their music feels authentic and relaxing, perfect for appreciating the culture while traveling.

When I travel, especially road trips across the USA, I love blasting classic rock bands like Led Zeppelin and The Rolling Stones. Their energetic tunes keep me pumped and make the journey way more fun.

For flying or long train rides, I usually go for some upbeat fast food chain playlists or throw on some contemporary rock artists like Foo Fighters or Imagine Dragons. It’s a good vibe that matches the excitement of exploring new places.

If I’m driving through cityscapes or scenic routes, I enjoy mixing in some pasta restaurant jazz playlists or alternative rock like Red Hot Chili Peppers. It’s a cool way to blend my love for good food and rock music while on the road.

I find that classical music, especially composers like Mozart or Vivaldi, enhances the travel experience. Their timeless pieces create a relaxing atmosphere whether you're flying or exploring European cities. It pairs well with the scenery and the sense of history around you.

When traveling, I like to listen to orchestral music that reflects the culture of the place I’m visiting. For example, if I’m in Vienna, I’ll play works by Beethoven or Brahms to get into the city's classical roots while enjoying a hearty meat-based meal at a traditional restaurant.

For long journeys, I prefer soundtracks from classical opera or symphonies. Listening to Puccini or Tchaikovsky can make the trip feel more like a grand adventure, especially when traveling through Europe’s historical landmarks and enjoying regional dishes centered around meat.
